question: Question_B_02_(b)
statement:
Let $A = (0,1,2)$, $B = (1,0,3)$ and $C = (1,1,4)$. Let $\Delta$ be the
triangle whose vertices are \emph{A},\emph{B}, and \emph{C}.

Prove that $\Delta$ is a right-angled triangle.
sols:
Let

$\vec{AB} = B-A = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix}0 & 1 & 2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix}1 & -1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

and let

$\vec{BC} = C-B = \begin{bmatrix}1 & 1 & 4 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix}1 & 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix}  = \begin{bmatrix}0 & 1 & 1 \end{bmatrix}$

as in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH152/April_2013/Question_B_02_(a)}{part
(a)}. The vector are orthogonal if their dot product is zero.
Calculating this dot product yields

$\vec{AB} \cdot \vec{BC} = (1)(0) + (-1)(1) + (1)(1) = 0$

Thus, vectors $\vec{BA}$ and $\vec{CB}$ are orthogonal and so the
triangle is right angled.
hints:
There is a relationship between the dot product of two vectors and these
vectors being orthogonal, do you know what it is?
